text: BR17120 Genetics, Evolution and Diversity: SES. Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Objectives and learning outcomes. On successful completion of this module students should be able to:  Describe genetic processes at all levels of organisation (e.g. molecular, chromosomal, population) with reference to appropriate structures and concepts.  Carry out genetic experiments in the laboratory, using appropriate equipment and techniques, and analyse and interpret the resulting data.  Outline the key phases in the evolution of life on Earth, describe the evolution of major groups of organisms and identify the anatomical links between extinct and living life forms. Objectives and learning outcomes. On successful completion of this module students should be able to:  Compare and contrast the morphology and anatomy of the major groups, be able to identify representatives of the groups and describe their key features and physiological adaptations in the context of environmental conditions.  Explain how different biological classification systems are defined and used and describe the diversity and evolutionary history of a taxon of organisms through the construction of a basic phylogenetic tree and accompanying narrative. Changes made to this module as a result of student feedback.  New module but student feedback used in development:  Timing of the practicals.  Introduction of additional coursework support sessions to help you with your coursework.  Introduction of more material on vertebrates. Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Objectives and learning outcomes.  Tetrapod origins  Amphibians  Introduction to amniotes – Reptiles – Birds – Mammals Tetrapods are gnathostomes that have limbs  One most significant events vert history ~ 360 MYA – fins lobe-fins evolved - limbs & feet tetrapods. – fish fins for “walking” – frogfish – http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F8VyOuJ8Uak&featu re=related  Tetrapod – “four feet”.  Limbs in place of pectoral & pelvic fins – Support weight on land – Transmit muscle generated forces to ground. Life on land brought other changes to tetrapod body plan  Head separated from body by neck – Originally 1 vertebra – up/down – Evolution second vertebra – sideways  Bones pelvic girdle fused to backbone – forces from hind legs transferred to whole body  Extant tetrapods no gill slits – Embryonic pharyngeal clefts give rise to other structures  Some characteristics altered/lost in various tetrapod lineages Tetrapod origins…  Modification - pre existing body plan  In 1 lobe-fin lineage – Fins - more limb-like – Retained adaptations for aquatic life  Acanthostega – Greenland 365 MYA – Fully formed legs, ankles & digits – Bones supporting gills – Tail – rays supporting fin – Weak pectoral & pelvic girdles - support body? – Slithered out of water occasionally? – Mostly aquatic. Dr Jennifer Clack http://chem.tufts.edu/science/e volution/fish-amphibian- transition.htm Tetrapod origins…  Over last 20 years – Fossils - confident reconstruction tetrapod origins.  During Devonian & Carboniferous - great diversity tetrapods emerged.  Most early tetrapods probably remained tied to water. Amphibians… Class Amphibia ~6150 species, 3 orders.  Order Urodela – “tailed ones” – salamanders – ~ 550 species  Order Anura – “tail-less ones” – frogs – ~ 5420 species  Order Apoda – “leg-less ones” - caecilians – ~ 170 species http://www.jacksonvillezoo.org/listingDetails.asp x?listingID=7022&pageID=15577 https://www.pinterest.co.uk/pin/557179785119716674/ https://www.picquery.com/c/class- amphibia_2Xu3pzDhvtuZIROOcqWWbRtlUcmX9mq URK%7C86Zutz1Q/ Order Urodela…  Some entirely aquatic.  Others - on land as adults or throughout life.  Terrestrial sp. - walk - side-to-side bending body.  Paedomorphosis common aquatic salamanders – E.g. Mexican axolotl – retains larval features when sexually mature http://www.jacksonvillezoo.org/listingDetails.asp x?listingID=7022&pageID=15577 http://auuuu.com/ Order Anura…  More specialised than urodeles for moving on land.  Adults – powerful hind legs.  Tongue – prey capture/feeding.  Defence – distasteful/poisonous mucus.  Colouration – Defence – Camouflage. https://www.pinterest.co.uk/pin/557179785119716674/ Rittmeyer EN, Allison A, Gründler MC, Thompson DK, Austin CC - E. N. Rittmeyer et al. (2012). "Ecological Guild Evolution and the Discovery of the World's Smallest Vertebrate". PLoS ONE 7: e29797. DOI:10.1371/journal.pone.0029797. → Figure 2 → tiff, CC BY 2.5, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?c urid=18014488 Order Apoda…  Legless – secondarily derived condition – Evolved from legged ancestor  Nearly blind.  Tropical.  Most burrow - moist forest soil.  Some South American sp. – f.w. habitats. https://www.picquery.com/c/class- amphibia_2Xu3pzDhvtuZIROOcqWWbRtlUcmX9mq URK%7C86Zutz1Q/ Amphibians…  Amphibian – amphibious – “both ways of life”.  Anuran larval stage – tadpole – usually aquatic herbivore.  Metamorphosis – – develops legs, lungs, external eardrums, digestive system adapted to carnivory. Gills disappear, & lateral line system disappears in many sp.  Not all - dual aquatic – terrestrial life – Some strictly aquatic, some strictly terrestrial anurans.  Urodele & apodan larvae look like adults – typically both larvae & adults carnivorous. Amphibians…  Most - damp habitats e.g. swamps rainforests – Drier climates - burrows & under vegetation  Moist skin – gas exchange – Some terrestrial sp. lack lungs - breathe skin & oral cavity.  Mostly external fertilisation – Shell – less eggs laid in water/moist environments – desiccation  Various types parental care – mobile nurseries (back, mouth stomach).  Some ovoviviparous & viviparous species. Amphibian decline…  Last 30-40 years dramatic decline in populations – Habitat loss – Fungal (chytrid) disease – Climate change – Pollution  Since 1980 at least 9 sp. extinct.  Another 113 sp. - “possibly extinct”. http://www.jacksonvillezoo.org/listingDetails.asp x?listingID=7022&pageID=15577 https://www.pinterest.co.uk/pin/557179785119716674/ https://www.picquery.com/c/class- amphibia_2Xu3pzDhvtuZIROOcqWWbRtlUcmX9mq URK%7C86Zutz1Q/ Amniotes are tetrapods that have a terrestrially adapted egg Extant amniotes  Reptiles & birds  Mammals Derived amniote characteristics  Amniotic egg  4 extraembryonic membranes  Amnion, chorion, yolk sac, allantois  Amniotic eggs of most reptiles & some mammals - shell http://tolweb.org/Amniota The Amniotic egg.  Colonization land by vertebrates.  Amniote - extra-embryonic membranes  Not found in anamniote vertebrates (fish & amphibia).  Evolutionary reasons unclear – increased size & strength. http://tolweb.org/Amniota The Amniotic egg. Biological engineering!  Protection – shell - leathery / calcified.  Respiration – shell – gases & water.  Respiration – amnion & chorion vascularized.  Respiration/excretion – allantois – vascularized.  Nutrition/protection – albumen.  Nutrition – egg yolk. http://tolweb.org/Amniota Other adaptations for life on land  Rib cage to ventilate lungs. – More efficient than throat-based ventilation. – Amphibians use method to supplement respiration via skin.  Did increased efficiency rib cage ventilation allow amniotes to abandon respiration via skin? – Less permeable skin? – Water conservation? Early amniotes  Most recent common ancestor living amphibians & amniotes ~ 370 MYA.  No amniotic egg fossils. Evidence from amniote fossils – Could live in drier climates than 1st tetrapods – Some herbivores – grinding teeth. – Some predators.
